order_book.pipeline_commentary: Exit deal pipeline is higher by over 30% versus Q4FY24.

financial_analysis.performance_summary: FSL achieved a milestone in Q4 FY25 by reaching a US$1 billion annualized revenue run rate, exceeding its target by four quarters. FY25 revenue grew by 25.9% in INR and 23.3% in USD, exceeding guidance. EBIT margin for FY25 was 11.1% (excluding one-offs), within the guided range. PAT grew by 15.5% YoY to INR 5.94 billion. Q4 saw strong revenue growth (29.4% YoY in INR), with EBIT margin expanding by 20 bps YoY and PAT growing by 22.6% YoY (normalized).

latest_quarter.narrative: Q4 FY25 revenue showed robust growth of 29.4% YoY in INR and 24.3% YoY in USD, driven by deal ramp-ups and seasonal strength in collections. EBIT margin improved by 20 bps YoY to 11.2%, driven by operational efficiencies and cost optimization initiatives. PAT increased by 22.6% YoY (normalized), benefiting from revenue growth and margin expansion. QoQ growth in constant currency revenue was 2.1%, with EBIT margin up by 10 bps and normalized PAT up by 6.1%. Suitable charts would be bar charts comparing revenues, EBIT, and PAT across Q3 and Q4 FY25 and Q4 FY24, and line charts showing margin trends.

full_year.narrative: FY25 revenue demonstrated strong growth of 25.9% YoY in INR and 23.3% YoY in USD, driven by successful execution of the company's strategic initiatives and strong deal wins. Operating margin remained relatively stable at 11.0% (11.1% excluding one-offs), reflecting investments in the business offset by cost optimization efforts. The trajectory over FY25 was of stable margins with slight improvement in the last three quarters.  Wage hikes, productivity pass-backs, cost optimization and the impact of deal ramp-ups/delays were key factors influencing margins. A suitable chart would be a line chart showing operating margin trends across the four quarters of FY25.

financial_analysis.segment_geographic_deep_dive: BFS grew by 12% YoY in CC terms, driven by deal ramp-ups and seasonal collections strength. Healthcare saw modest sequential growth in Q4 due to a previous slowdown in deal-making, but momentum is picking up with strong deal wins. CMT grew by 12% YoY in CC terms, driven by traction in consumer tech. The diverse segment declined by 9% QoQ in CC terms due to retail seasonality. Geographically, North America grew by 30% YoY in CC terms, while Europe declined by 3% QoQ in CC terms due to UK retail softness. Australia showed strong growth. No client-specific issues were mentioned.
financial_analysis.deal_wins_pipeline_quality: FSL signed five large deals in Q4 and 14 in FY25, the highest ever, including four deals with ACV over US$10 million. The deal pipeline is strong, with the exit pipeline up 30% over Q4 FY24. Deals are increasingly transformative and include BPaaS offerings, indicating a shift towards more strategic and long-term partnerships.  A notable win was a US$50+ million ACV BPaaS deal in healthcare.  Management believes the deal wins reflect their success in leveraging industry expertise, technology partnerships, and automation/AI capabilities.
financial_analysis.management_commentary_outlook: For FY26, management expects revenue growth of 12-15% in CC terms and EBIT margin of 11.25-12%. The guidance reflects the current business outlook and does not incorporate potential macro changes. Management is focused on continuing to win deals, improving conversion rates, and managing the ramp-up of transformative deals.
financial_analysis.comparison_to_expectations: FY25 CC revenue growth of 22.6% exceeded the higher end of the guided range (21.8% to 22.3%). FY25 EBIT margin (excluding one-offs) of 11.1% was within the guided range of 11% to 11.5%. Q4 revenue exceeded internal expectations, with the business reaching a US$1 billion run rate four quarters ahead of guidance.
financial_analysis.key_risks_headwinds: Management mentioned macro uncertainties, particularly in the UK, and a slowdown in decision-making in healthcare during Q2 FY25. They also highlighted the potential disruption of the BPO industry by AI and the need for companies to adapt their business models.
financial_analysis.operational_efficiency: DSO was 70 days in Q4, but normalized to 67 days after accounting for delayed collections. TTM attrition decreased to 29.8% in Q4 and is expected to continue improving.  Headcount increased by 6,711 in FY25, with 80% of gross additions in offshore and nearshore locations.  Utilization rate was not provided. The company invested heavily in upskilling, delivering over 200,000 digital learning hours.
